content.text: That sure was a nice move breaking through 73. I'm seeing a slight consolidation and then rally into earnings. Zoom is finally moving higher from here. $100 at least by years end if earnings show any growth.

You're dumb if you shorted this stock. While this stock has low growth, it's only a matter of time before something good happened. A lot of cash, no debt, P/FCF low, good brand recognition. Potential upside is huge: either buying a company to increase growth, or bought by other bigger company, stock buyback, or change management to someone with great vision, all are good. In the meantime, currently, it's still making a lot of money, revenue still growing, all good.
Agreed.

This company has a 2.09% year over year revenue growth and that was beat by 1.12% in the July earnings report. For that they reward the stock with a 40% pop off the lows. I value this value stock around 31-40.00 based on the balance sheet. A p/e of 26 is much too high for a value stock. I see no reason to buy here just to be a part of the plunge that's coming. If you like this company there will be better entry points. Not a good long entry point. Day traders and momentum players are pushing their luck.

I'd like to take this opportunity to share the news that after almost 7 years, Kelly has made the decision to leave Zoom. Kelly joined Zoom about 2 years before our successful IPO in April 2019, and her role in that has been a highlight of her time here. She will leverage her skills in helping companies scale and building successful businesses to help another startup in that process for the next Zoom.She has been an integral part of the Zoom journey, steering our IPO in 2019 and continuing the momentum as our customer base rapidly expanded during the pandemic. Under her strong financial leadership, Zoom has maintained a consistent track record of profitability and cash flow growth.

Even if you use discounted cash flow analysis, this stock hardly has any room to the upside. 

IF you belive it can generate 2% rev growth, 18% margins, 36% FCF as % of revenue, 16 PE, and 16 P/FCF for the next 5 years, you only get a price of $66.18. That's using ONLY discounted cash flow, if you do the same for multiple of earnings, its $33.09 that would be almost 50% drop from here. 

Reminder: P/FCF is currently 11, I put it as 16! If I put it as 9 (assuming they increase cash flow), it comes out to 44.

With $22 per share in cash and a PE of 11 on non-GAAP earnings of $5 this stock seems too good to be true. Apparently, non-GAAP earnings don't include the expense of issuing 3 million shares a year to employees. So, in reality, GAAP earnings are much lower, closer to $2 per share. Then the current share price of $56 makes a bit more sense. The company has initiated a share buyback program which should more than offset all the shares paid to employees, but that will lessen the cash position. If there were any growth here, the stock could be cheap. Wall St. has figured out this company will not grow very much and has it priced accordingly.
